episodes.description: Consultative sales is not like regular sales. This session explains how to position yourself as a trusted advisor, partner and peer to your customers, clearly differentiating yourself from other salespeople.
episodes.title: Section One: The Right Mindset
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:04.054 --> 00:00:07.449
First thing you have to do to be
a successful consultative sales person

2
00:00:07.449 --> 00:00:09.740
is have the right mindset.

3
00:00:09.740 --> 00:00:12.350
You don't wanna think of
yourself as a sales person.

4
00:00:12.350 --> 00:00:14.420
You wanna think of
yourself as a consultant.

5
00:00:14.420 --> 00:00:17.520
You wanna be insanely curious,
ask great questions.

6
00:00:18.570 --> 00:00:22.010
Treat your client,
customer with tremendous respect.

7
00:00:22.010 --> 00:00:23.250
Be very professional.

8
00:00:24.410 --> 00:00:26.250
Actually, let me help you out with this.

9
00:00:26.250 --> 00:00:29.760
Often times when I teach this course,
I'll ask the audience,

10
00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:33.620
what do you think of when you
think of the typical salesperson?

11
00:00:33.620 --> 00:00:35.610
And here's the sort of things I hear.

12
00:00:35.610 --> 00:00:36.720
They talk too much.

13
00:00:36.720 --> 00:00:37.610
They're aggressive.

14
00:00:37.610 --> 00:00:38.710
They're rude.

15
00:00:38.710 --> 00:00:40.340
They don't know anything about me.

16
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:41.690
If it's a business to business thing,

17
00:00:41.690 --> 00:00:45.060
it's they don't know anything
about my business or my customers.

18
00:00:45.060 --> 00:00:46.950
They're constantly talking
about their product.

19
00:00:46.950 --> 00:00:49.630
They only care about their commission.

20
00:00:49.630 --> 00:00:50.780
And the biggest thing, and

21
00:00:50.780 --> 00:00:54.600
it's the one that I hear from the most
senior executives, is the reason

22
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:59.790
I won't see a salesperson or talk to
a salesperson is they waste my time.

23
00:00:59.790 --> 00:01:02.040
I could almost end the course right here,
but I won't,

24
00:01:02.040 --> 00:01:04.600
because there's a lot of other
stuff I gotta teach you.

25
00:01:04.600 --> 00:01:07.330
But if you truly want to
be a great salesperson,

26
00:01:07.330 --> 00:01:09.820
just do the reverse of all that stuff.

27
00:01:09.820 --> 00:01:11.970
Be extremely professional.

28
00:01:11.970 --> 00:01:15.220
See sales as a craft, as a noble craft.

29
00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:18.010
Do only what's in your
client's best interest.

30
00:01:18.010 --> 00:01:19.230
Ask lots of questions.

31
00:01:19.230 --> 00:01:20.990
Write great notes.

32
00:01:20.990 --> 00:01:23.794
Listen intently.

33
00:01:23.794 --> 00:01:26.806
Only focus on what they need,
what's important to them,

34
00:01:26.806 --> 00:01:29.230
getting them the exact right solution.

35
00:01:29.230 --> 00:01:32.320
Don't worry about your commission.

36
00:01:32.320 --> 00:01:34.250
You're gonna be fine.

37
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:36.450
Treat them as a partner, as a peer.

38
00:01:36.450 --> 00:01:38.230
Be extremely well-prepared.

39
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:39.030
Have an agenda.

40
00:01:39.030 --> 00:01:43.940
Do all the things that position
you as a true trusted advisor,

41
00:01:43.940 --> 00:01:47.490
as a consultant, a friend,
a peer, a partner, and

42
00:01:47.490 --> 00:01:51.100
most importantly is,
don't waste a single minute of their time.

43
00:01:51.100 --> 00:01:54.060
Make sure that you're there,
totally focused on them,

44
00:01:54.060 --> 00:01:58.940
doing everything you can to help them,
extremely prepared, ready to

45
00:01:58.940 --> 00:02:02.670
make sure that you're meeting with them is
a great, great investment of their time.

46
00:02:02.670 --> 00:02:07.050
And you're gonna help them find
a perfect solution for their problem.

47
00:02:07.050 --> 00:02:11.180
If you really wanna be a consultant or
a salesperson, that's the first step.

48
00:02:11.180 --> 00:02:13.810
So when we look at what it
takes to be a trusted advisor,

49
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:16.820
there's a pyramid I use to describe this.

50
00:02:16.820 --> 00:02:21.050
At the base of the pyramid is
just general business knowledge.

51
00:02:21.050 --> 00:02:24.680
You gotta know what's going on in
your town, in the economy, globally.

52
00:02:24.680 --> 00:02:26.520
It doesn't mean you need
to know everything, but

53
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:27.710
you need to keep up with stuff.

54
00:02:27.710 --> 00:02:31.890
So this is reading the Wall Street
Journal, reading your local paper,

55
00:02:31.890 --> 00:02:35.190
maybe watching a little bit of news,
not too much, it'll depress you.

56
00:02:35.190 --> 00:02:37.300
But just keeping up on the general trends,

57
00:02:37.300 --> 00:02:42.265
the general economy, what's happening in
business, so that at least you can speak

58
00:02:42.265 --> 00:02:46.095
knowledgeably about what's happening
in the general business arena.

59
00:02:46.095 --> 00:02:50.245
The next level, and this is critical,
is you must be an expert, and

60
00:02:50.245 --> 00:02:51.825
I do not use that work lightly.

61
00:02:51.825 --> 00:02:55.560
I mean an expert on your products and
services.

62
00:02:55.560 --> 00:02:59.490
You've got to know that stuff
95% dead down pat perfect.

63
00:03:02.260 --> 00:03:05.980
Your allowed every now and then to say I
don't know let me go check with my office,

64
00:03:05.980 --> 00:03:07.750
let me talk to one of the engineers.

65
00:03:07.750 --> 00:03:11.320
Let me call back and see,
that's okay a few times.

66
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:14.650
But the vast majority of
the time you need to be a true

67
00:03:14.650 --> 00:03:18.650
expert about everything you sell,
about your products, about your services,

68
00:03:18.650 --> 00:03:21.060
about the warranty, about the pricing.

69
00:03:21.060 --> 00:03:24.230
Everything you can think
of that is table stakes.

70
00:03:24.230 --> 00:03:27.310
If you don't know your products and
services inside and

71
00:03:27.310 --> 00:03:32.690
out there is no way on the face of the
earth a customer/client will trust you.

72
00:03:32.690 --> 00:03:34.460
The next step, and
this is an interesting one,

73
00:03:34.460 --> 00:03:37.380
is you need to be an expert
on your competition.

74
00:03:37.380 --> 00:03:42.190
Really understand your entire industry,
understand who you compete against,

75
00:03:42.190 --> 00:03:45.370
what's going on in your industry,
who's making changes,

76
00:03:45.370 --> 00:03:49.460
who has new innovations, and
I'm even going to go one step further.

77
00:03:49.460 --> 00:03:52.260
You should know your competition
well enough, their products,

78
00:03:52.260 --> 00:03:56.590
their services, all of them, that you
can make referrals to your clients and

79
00:03:56.590 --> 00:04:00.080
customers if you don't have the right
product or service for them.

80
00:04:00.080 --> 00:04:04.380
If you can't give them the exact right
solution, something that will truly

81
00:04:04.380 --> 00:04:08.410
solve their problem and help them, then
if you want to be a trusted advisor and

82
00:04:08.410 --> 00:04:12.570
a great constitutive sales person, you
will refer them off to your competition.

83
00:04:12.570 --> 00:04:15.835
And you should know your competition
well enough that you understand that

84
00:04:15.835 --> 00:04:19.155
they have the products or
services that will solve their problem.

85
00:04:19.155 --> 00:04:21.815
So in addition to being an expert
on your company, your products,

86
00:04:21.815 --> 00:04:27.105
your services, you need to be an expert on
your industry and your major competition.

87
00:04:27.105 --> 00:04:32.040
Last but most important, you must
become an expert on your customer.

88
00:04:32.040 --> 00:04:37.020
If it's a B to B situation, you need
to understand their business very well.

89
00:04:37.020 --> 00:04:37.970
Who do they sell to?

90
00:04:37.970 --> 00:04:39.580
How do they make money?

91
00:04:39.580 --> 00:04:41.050
What are their unique processes?

92
00:04:41.050 --> 00:04:44.170
What's differentiated about their product?

93
00:04:44.170 --> 00:04:46.210
How are they positioned
in the market place?

94
00:04:46.210 --> 00:04:48.810
Everything you can possibly understand.

95
00:04:48.810 --> 00:04:51.030
And for
a lot of people this feels awkward,

96
00:04:51.030 --> 00:04:53.680
like how am I gonna find
out all these information.

97
00:04:53.680 --> 00:04:58.380
Just remember that as a trusted advisor
if you're truly a partner to them,

98
00:04:58.380 --> 00:05:01.060
you have the right and
the obligation to know as

99
00:05:01.060 --> 00:05:06.055
much as you possibly can about their
business so you can help their business.

100
00:05:06.055 --> 00:05:08.735
And if you've got someone who's not
willing to share that information with

101
00:05:08.735 --> 00:05:12.405
you, they have told you that
see you as a vendor [LAUGH] and

102
00:05:12.405 --> 00:05:14.885
they're probably gonna
beat you up on price.

103
00:05:14.885 --> 00:05:19.415
So you've got to become as much as
possible an expert on you customer.

104
00:05:19.415 --> 00:05:22.825
Do your homework, go to their website,
read their industry journals,

105
00:05:22.825 --> 00:05:24.960
find out everything you can about them.

106
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:28.130
And if this is a business
to consumers sale,

107
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:31.860
you need to find out as much as they
will share with you about them.

108
00:05:31.860 --> 00:05:36.010
What's their family situation, if you
need to know, let's give you an example.

109
00:05:36.010 --> 00:05:38.576
I've worked for a lot of boat companies.

110
00:05:38.576 --> 00:05:42.405
And I work for one of the top
ski boat companies in the world,

111
00:05:42.405 --> 00:05:45.750
MasterCraft, and
I've been helping their sales people.

112
00:05:45.750 --> 00:05:49.090
And some of the things you need to know
are, what's their family situation?

113
00:05:49.090 --> 00:05:50.590
How many kids do they have?

114
00:05:50.590 --> 00:05:51.660
How old are their kids?

115
00:05:51.660 --> 00:05:53.500
Do their kids already like to ski?

116
00:05:53.500 --> 00:05:55.780
Does their husband or wife like to ski?

117
00:05:55.780 --> 00:05:57.130
Have they owned other boats?

118
00:05:57.130 --> 00:05:59.750
Are they a knowledgeable boat owner?

119
00:05:59.750 --> 00:06:02.500
It would even help to know
what kind of car they drive,

120
00:06:02.500 --> 00:06:05.800
where they go on vacation,
what kind of sports they like.

121
00:06:05.800 --> 00:06:09.210
Because that will help you
understand the customer better and

122
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:13.330
be able to position them and put them in
the right boat that is exactly right for

123
00:06:13.330 --> 00:06:14.530
them and their family.

124
00:06:14.530 --> 00:06:17.790
So the more you know about the customer
and everything about them,

125
00:06:17.790 --> 00:06:21.460
the better job you can do of helping
them buy what's exactly right for them.

126
00:06:21.460 --> 00:06:26.580
You notice I didn't say sell them,
helping them purchase exactly what they

127
00:06:26.580 --> 00:06:30.190
want to solve their problems or to have
more fun on the water or to make their

128
00:06:30.190 --> 00:06:35.640
family happy or whatever it might be as
it pertains to your product and service.

129
00:06:35.640 --> 00:06:37.270
Here's something you need to understand.

130
00:06:37.270 --> 00:06:41.420
The first two levels, having general
business knowledge and being a true

131
00:06:41.420 --> 00:06:46.250
expert on your products and services,
basically gets you no extra credit at all.

132
00:06:46.250 --> 00:06:46.940
That's expected.

133
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:51.800
If you're gonna sell something to me, you
ought to know at least those two things.

134
00:06:51.800 --> 00:06:54.010
So that's of little or no value.

135
00:06:54.010 --> 00:06:57.480
At the next level, understanding your
competition and being an expert on your

136
00:06:57.480 --> 00:07:01.820
industry and your competition, now you're
starting to add a medium level of value.

137
00:07:01.820 --> 00:07:03.690
Because not every sales person does that.

138
00:07:03.690 --> 00:07:05.950
Matter of fact, few sales people do that.

139
00:07:05.950 --> 00:07:11.080
But when you jump to that top level of
truly becoming an expert on your customer,

140
00:07:11.080 --> 00:07:13.120
now you're adding massive value.

141
00:07:13.120 --> 00:07:16.520
Now you're positioning
yourself as a trusted advisor,

142
00:07:16.520 --> 00:07:20.430
someone that they wanna partner with,
someone they want on their team.

143
00:07:20.430 --> 00:07:24.360
And the reason is when you get to that
level, you're not just answering requests,

144
00:07:24.360 --> 00:07:27.690
you're not just,
they say they have a problem you solve it.

145
00:07:27.690 --> 00:07:30.570
You're actually proactively
thinking of problems

146
00:07:30.570 --> 00:07:32.410
that they don't even know that they have.

147
00:07:32.410 --> 00:07:35.370
You're coming up with solutions that
are better than they thought they could

148
00:07:35.370 --> 00:07:35.960
come up with.

149
00:07:36.980 --> 00:07:39.700
You are adding massive value because
basically you are able to see

150
00:07:39.700 --> 00:07:40.920
around the corner.

151
00:07:40.920 --> 00:07:43.410
You know as much about their business
as some of the people there,

152
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:46.840
you know a lot about their industry and
then you know about your products and

153
00:07:46.840 --> 00:07:49.430
services and
all the ways you can help them.

154
00:07:49.430 --> 00:07:52.382
And this is another way where
you do cross selling and

155
00:07:52.382 --> 00:07:56.877
you increase your share of wallet by not
just selling of one solution but helping

156
00:07:56.877 --> 00:08:01.169
them purchase multiple solutions or
come back and purchase from you over and

157
00:08:01.169 --> 00:08:04.756
over again because you add so
much value, they get so much ROI.

158
00:08:04.756 --> 00:08:09.244
Or if it's an individual purchase, they
really enjoy the shopping, buying, and

159
00:08:09.244 --> 00:08:12.065
owning experience of your products and
services and

160
00:08:12.065 --> 00:08:14.460
they want to do more business with you.

161
00:08:14.460 --> 00:08:18.090
And they become a customer evangelist,
someone that sends you referrals.

162
00:08:18.090 --> 00:08:20.760
At the very top of this pyramid,
when you're a consultative,

163
00:08:20.760 --> 00:08:24.600
trusted advisor, you have a lot of value.

164
00:08:24.600 --> 00:08:29.310
And it's very hard to get you out
of there because they trust you,

165
00:08:29.310 --> 00:08:31.000
the switching cost is high.

166
00:08:31.000 --> 00:08:34.840
And you have differentiated yourself
as a sales person dramatically

167
00:08:34.840 --> 00:08:36.480
from your competition.

168
00:08:36.480 --> 00:08:40.450
And they really trust you which
means it's easier to make the sale.

169
00:08:40.450 --> 00:08:43.040
They don't argue about prices much.

170
00:08:43.040 --> 00:08:47.110
And if they get the ROI they want,
either personal or business, they're

171
00:08:47.110 --> 00:08:51.680
going to continue to do lots of business
with you and that's what we're all after.

172
00:08:51.680 --> 00:08:54.800
So far I've already talked a lot
about trust, being a trusted advisor.

173
00:08:54.800 --> 00:09:00.450
So I want to share with you a matrix our
firm created around how to create trust.

174
00:09:00.450 --> 00:09:03.990
And we call this the four Cs of trust,
and I might add a fifth here for today.

175
00:09:03.990 --> 00:09:06.250
But the four Cs of trust are,

176
00:09:06.250 --> 00:09:11.430
you must Consistently Communicate
that you are Competent and you Care.

177
00:09:11.430 --> 00:09:15.029
Here's the matrix right here, and
in the far bottom-right corner,

178
00:09:15.029 --> 00:09:18.360
you've got someone with high
competence but low concern.

179
00:09:18.360 --> 00:09:21.430
They're brilliant, I mean they're genius,
they know their products and services,

180
00:09:21.430 --> 00:09:24.265
they know their industry,
they know everything, but they're an ass.

181
00:09:24.265 --> 00:09:26.960
[LAUGH] Do you trust this person?

182
00:09:26.960 --> 00:09:30.397
No, nobody trusts this kinda person
because they're rude, arrogant,

183
00:09:30.397 --> 00:09:31.440
condescending.

184
00:09:31.440 --> 00:09:33.196
The word I use here is respect.

185
00:09:33.196 --> 00:09:36.740
I respect their competence,
I respect their intelligence.

186
00:09:36.740 --> 00:09:39.540
But I do not trust them cuz I
know they don't care about me.

187
00:09:39.540 --> 00:09:43.110
They only care about themselves and
showing off how smart, bright, and

188
00:09:43.110 --> 00:09:44.180
talented they are.

189
00:09:44.180 --> 00:09:45.850
I'm glad they're competent but

190
00:09:45.850 --> 00:09:49.440
I don't want to do business with them
because I don't deeply trust them.

191
00:09:49.440 --> 00:09:54.482
The next one in the lower left-hand corner
is I'm incompetent and I don't care.

192
00:09:54.482 --> 00:09:58.595
Yeah, I'm rude, aggressive, nasty, and
I have no idea what I'm talking about.

193
00:09:58.595 --> 00:10:02.940
[LAUGH] It does not work in sales at all.

194
00:10:02.940 --> 00:10:04.650
This is distrust.

195
00:10:04.650 --> 00:10:09.480
And no one will be successful in any
kind of business with low competence and

196
00:10:09.480 --> 00:10:11.010
low concern.

197
00:10:11.010 --> 00:10:15.910
Okay now in the upper left-hand corner
we've got someone with high concern but

198
00:10:15.910 --> 00:10:17.260
low competence.

199
00:10:17.260 --> 00:10:19.020
And unfortunately I see
this in sales a lot.

200
00:10:19.020 --> 00:10:21.580
This is somebody who's really nice.

201
00:10:21.580 --> 00:10:25.470
They swing by and bring you donuts or
invite you out to play golf or

202
00:10:25.470 --> 00:10:27.190
take you out to dinner.

203
00:10:27.190 --> 00:10:29.080
But they're hoping that
the relationship and

204
00:10:29.080 --> 00:10:33.520
the relationship only will
sell the product or service.

205
00:10:33.520 --> 00:10:34.580
And that happens very,

206
00:10:34.580 --> 00:10:38.050
very rarely will people give you
business just cuz they like you.

207
00:10:38.050 --> 00:10:42.180
But if you want to have continued business
and get word of mouth referrals and

208
00:10:42.180 --> 00:10:46.040
grow the business and be a true
consultative sales person at the highest

209
00:10:46.040 --> 00:10:50.680
level, affection alone won't help you and
that's what I call this level, affection.

210
00:10:50.680 --> 00:10:54.900
This is somebody who's really friendly,
I love hanging out with them.

211
00:10:54.900 --> 00:10:57.810
They're great but when I ask them
about their product, they don't know,

212
00:10:57.810 --> 00:10:59.460
they can't answer.

213
00:10:59.460 --> 00:11:02.780
When I ask them about the competitive
product, they don't know.

214
00:11:02.780 --> 00:11:05.720
They know very little about my business,
they're not asking a lot of questions.

215
00:11:05.720 --> 00:11:06.770
Again, I like them but

216
00:11:06.770 --> 00:11:11.430
I don't trust them because I don't feel
that they're competent enough to help me.

217
00:11:11.430 --> 00:11:13.920
And to play a major role in my business.

218
00:11:13.920 --> 00:11:18.600
Now the last quadrant at
the very top right hand is trust.

219
00:11:18.600 --> 00:11:21.820
And this is someone with high
competence and high concern.

220
00:11:21.820 --> 00:11:25.880
High competence, high concern and
the fifth C I'm gonna add is character.

221
00:11:25.880 --> 00:11:27.630
I would say that goes
along with competence, but

222
00:11:27.630 --> 00:11:30.130
one of the folks in my classes
pointed that out lately, and

223
00:11:30.130 --> 00:11:33.900
I thought it was nice, so high competence,
high concern, high character.

224
00:11:33.900 --> 00:11:37.150
This is someone who is extremely
knowledgeable, very talent,

225
00:11:37.150 --> 00:11:41.820
a true expert on their products, their
services, their industry, the competition,

226
00:11:41.820 --> 00:11:46.560
and their customers' business and
they're also very friendly.

227
00:11:46.560 --> 00:11:48.920
They have a high connection.

228
00:11:48.920 --> 00:11:52.450
So basically I can wrap this
whole idea up into this.

229
00:11:52.450 --> 00:11:57.000
What a true consultative person
does by consistently communicating

230
00:11:57.000 --> 00:12:00.740
that they're competent in their
care is say to the customer/client,

231
00:12:00.740 --> 00:12:04.325
I'm good at what I do and
I do it because I care about you.

232
00:12:04.325 --> 00:12:06.690
That's a really big idea.

233
00:12:06.690 --> 00:12:11.060
I teach this in leadership as well but
if you want to build a high level of trust

234
00:12:11.060 --> 00:12:14.300
you have to consistently communicate
that you're competent, you care.

235
00:12:14.300 --> 00:12:18.570
And show all of your customers I'm good
at what I do, getting better every day,

236
00:12:18.570 --> 00:12:23.163
I'm studying, I'm learning, I'm always
bringing new ideas, new innovations,

237
00:12:23.163 --> 00:12:27.090
new suggestions, I'm really good at
what I do and I do it all for you.

238
00:12:27.090 --> 00:12:29.390
I always have your best
interests at heart.

239
00:12:29.390 --> 00:12:32.720
I will never sell you anything
that isn't exactly right for you.

240
00:12:32.720 --> 00:12:33.780
You can trust me.

241
00:12:33.780 --> 00:12:35.190
I'm on your team.

242
00:12:35.190 --> 00:12:37.110
That is how you build trust.

243
00:12:37.110 --> 00:12:40.480
Interesting point here,
it can take weeks, months, or

244
00:12:40.480 --> 00:12:44.540
years to build up that level of trust and
nanoseconds to lose it.

245
00:12:44.540 --> 00:12:47.680
So you gotta really guard
that reputation and

246
00:12:47.680 --> 00:12:51.360
you've got to be consistently learning,
growing, getting better, and

247
00:12:51.360 --> 00:12:55.680
prove everyday that you're always doing it
because you want to serve your customers,

248
00:12:55.680 --> 00:12:59.700
help them, and
always do what is in their best interest.

249
00:12:59.700 --> 00:13:04.570
Now I'm gonna teach you a very simple
idea but one that has huge ramifications.

250
00:13:05.710 --> 00:13:09.730
And here's the idea, and I learned this
from Mahan Kalsa who wrote an excellent

251
00:13:09.730 --> 00:13:13.700
book, I highly recommend it,
called Let's Get Real or Let's Not Play.

252
00:13:13.700 --> 00:13:19.490
One out of hundreds of sales book I've
read, absolutely in my top two or three.

253
00:13:19.490 --> 00:13:23.330
And I'm gonna talk about the other one
which is in the top two or three again.

254
00:13:24.440 --> 00:13:27.220
But here's the idea, listen carefully.

255
00:13:27.220 --> 00:13:29.980
Technique is nothing,
intent is everything.

256
00:13:31.020 --> 00:13:31.660
In other words,

257
00:13:31.660 --> 00:13:36.450
you could go to some of the sales training
places that teach you all the techniques,

258
00:13:36.450 --> 00:13:42.210
the tie-downs, the porcupine close, the
Ben Franklin close, the puppy dog close.

259
00:13:42.210 --> 00:13:46.860
How to sort of ask manipulative questions
that force people to say, yes, yes,

260
00:13:46.860 --> 00:13:49.930
yes, and
all these things that are techniques.

261
00:13:51.050 --> 00:13:54.720
But the truth of the matter is, most
customers see through that pretty quickly

262
00:13:54.720 --> 00:13:58.230
and if they catch you doing that,
you've automatically destroyed your trust

263
00:13:58.230 --> 00:14:01.240
cuz they realized it's a technique,
you're trying to manipulate them.

264
00:14:01.240 --> 00:14:05.440
The other side of the coin is if
your intent is to truly help them,

265
00:14:05.440 --> 00:14:10.230
let them get the exact right solution at a
good price that's reasonable and fair and

266
00:14:10.230 --> 00:14:15.040
a good profit for you, and they know that
your intent is to truly help them, you can

267
00:14:15.040 --> 00:14:19.150
actually mess up a lot of stuff and
they'll give you the benefit of the doubt.

268
00:14:19.150 --> 00:14:23.529
If you're not the most polished
salespeople in the world, and you don't

269
00:14:23.529 --> 00:14:28.473
run the best meeting but they know you're
really, really, really trying hard and

270
00:14:28.473 --> 00:14:33.153
your intent is to help them as much as
you can, they'll overlook a lot of that.

271
00:14:33.153 --> 00:14:37.488
Now, if you have,
you don't use the slimy techniques and

272
00:14:37.488 --> 00:14:43.800
you're also competent with great intent,
that is a winning combination.

273
00:14:43.800 --> 00:14:46.210
You show up and
you're not trying all these stupid closes,

274
00:14:46.210 --> 00:14:49.310
you're not trying to pressure them or
manipulate them.

275
00:14:49.310 --> 00:14:52.635
You're not trying for the aggressive
close right now, always be closing.

276
00:14:52.635 --> 00:14:59.170
[LAUGH] But you are professional,
you are kind, you're honest.

277
00:14:59.170 --> 00:15:00.340
You give them time.

278
00:15:00.340 --> 00:15:01.820
You give information.

279
00:15:01.820 --> 00:15:03.560
You help them.

280
00:15:03.560 --> 00:15:05.580
And you're extremely professional.

281
00:15:05.580 --> 00:15:08.040
You've got good questioning techniques.

282
00:15:08.040 --> 00:15:10.050
You've got good listening skills.

283
00:15:10.050 --> 00:15:11.730
You're taking great notes.

284
00:15:11.730 --> 00:15:13.660
You're asking the right kind of questions.

285
00:15:14.670 --> 00:15:17.920
And they can see you're doing all of
it because you want to help them.

286
00:15:17.920 --> 00:15:22.050
You've got positive technique plus
great intent, that's the way to do it.

287
00:15:22.050 --> 00:15:27.000
This is another small
idea with huge payback.

288
00:15:27.000 --> 00:15:29.620
This is actually one of the most
important things I ever learned in sales.

289
00:15:29.620 --> 00:15:33.000
When I figured this out it
totally changed the way

290
00:15:33.000 --> 00:15:38.110
I looked at my relationship with my
customers and clients and here's the idea.

291
00:15:38.110 --> 00:15:42.480
If you're truly gonna position yourself
as a trusted adviser and a partner,

292
00:15:42.480 --> 00:15:46.960
you got to realize that your job there
is to get the exact right solution for

293
00:15:46.960 --> 00:15:47.990
your customer.

294
00:15:47.990 --> 00:15:50.730
And you've heard me used that
terms several times because

295
00:15:50.730 --> 00:15:52.720
that's truly what you want.

296
00:15:52.720 --> 00:15:55.680
I used to think it was sort of
a battle between me and the customer.

297
00:15:55.680 --> 00:15:59.430
I was gonna try to get them there and
talk to them and convince them and

298
00:15:59.430 --> 00:16:03.060
sell them something and
then I felt bad about that.

299
00:16:03.060 --> 00:16:04.910
I didn't enjoy that kind of interaction.

300
00:16:04.910 --> 00:16:08.170
I felt like I was your
typical sales person.

301
00:16:08.170 --> 00:16:12.990
But when I learned that we both want
the same thing, both the customer and

302
00:16:12.990 --> 00:16:16.400
I want the same thing,
the exact right solution.

303
00:16:16.400 --> 00:16:18.810
Sell them the wrong product, just so

304
00:16:18.810 --> 00:16:21.200
you can make your commission,
lose them forever.

305
00:16:21.200 --> 00:16:24.940
Sell them a product at too high of
a price, they find that out, and

306
00:16:24.940 --> 00:16:27.760
then they go to your competition
to get a lower price.

307
00:16:27.760 --> 00:16:32.100
Sell them a product at too low of a price,
you go out of business,

308
00:16:32.100 --> 00:16:34.720
that's called bankruptcy,
you can't help them anymore.

309
00:16:34.720 --> 00:16:39.850
Sell them the exact right product at the
exact right price, then deliver it late.

310
00:16:39.850 --> 00:16:41.410
No more client.

311
00:16:41.410 --> 00:16:45.000
Sell them the exact right product
at the exact right price and

312
00:16:45.000 --> 00:16:48.760
then don't follow up and make sure that
it works well, again you lose the client.

313
00:16:48.760 --> 00:16:53.090
So you have to sell them the exact
right product at the exact right price

314
00:16:53.090 --> 00:16:55.620
which is a price you make
a reasonable profit at,

315
00:16:55.620 --> 00:16:58.110
a good profit cuz you
need to stay in business.

316
00:16:58.110 --> 00:17:00.030
You need to invest in R&D in your company.

317
00:17:00.030 --> 00:17:01.190
You've got to hire new people.

318
00:17:01.190 --> 00:17:03.040
You've got marketing costs.

319
00:17:03.040 --> 00:17:05.680
So if you've got a client that
really sees you as a partner,

320
00:17:05.680 --> 00:17:08.370
they understand you need
to make a profit too.

321
00:17:08.370 --> 00:17:11.750
So the goal here, again,
is to get the exact right solution.

322
00:17:11.750 --> 00:17:13.890
It's not you versus the customer.

323
00:17:13.890 --> 00:17:15.870
It's not you trying to win.

324
00:17:15.870 --> 00:17:19.930
It's you trying to make sure that
everybody wins so you can come back and

325
00:17:19.930 --> 00:17:23.960
do more and more business with them and
they'll refer more and more people to you.

326
00:17:23.960 --> 00:17:26.600
That's what a true sales
person focuses on.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:05.069 --> 00:00:08.900
In section one, I shared with
you a lot of really great ideas.

2
00:00:08.900 --> 00:00:10.000
Some very simple, but

3
00:00:10.000 --> 00:00:15.430
very powerful, about how to get the right
mindset to be a consultator salesperson.

4
00:00:15.430 --> 00:00:17.500
And again,
I wanna give credit where credit is due,

5
00:00:17.500 --> 00:00:20.120
a lot of that information
came from what I learned

6
00:00:20.120 --> 00:00:25.040
from Mahan Khalsa in his amazing book,
Let's Get Real and Let's Not Play.

7
00:00:25.040 --> 00:00:26.640
I highly recommend it.

8
00:00:26.640 --> 00:00:31.280
Now I want to shift gears and talk about
what it takes to differentiate yourself

9
00:00:31.280 --> 00:00:35.510
in the marketplace and be considered among
the best in the world at what you do.

10
00:00:35.510 --> 00:00:38.870
I've been teaching a class at
the Warton School of Business for

11
00:00:38.870 --> 00:00:43.590
about 15 years on strategic thinking and
strategic planning as a guest lecturer.

12
00:00:43.590 --> 00:00:46.110
And it's an executive level class.

13
00:00:46.110 --> 00:00:49.190
And it’s fairly complex there’s
some big ideas in there.

14
00:00:49.190 --> 00:00:54.270
But I want to sort of boil the entire
class down to one idea that sounds simple

15
00:00:54.270 --> 00:00:57.500
but is devilishly hard
to actually implement.

16
00:00:57.500 --> 00:00:59.470
So here’s the main idea.

17
00:00:59.470 --> 00:01:02.370
All effective strategy is just

18
00:01:02.370 --> 00:01:05.539
valued differentiation times
disciplined execution.

19
00:01:06.800 --> 00:01:09.700
Sounds easy but
here's what you gotta do to implement it.

20
00:01:10.700 --> 00:01:14.920
You've gotta bring something that's
unique, exciting, compelling to your

21
00:01:14.920 --> 00:01:20.020
customer that they're willing to pay for,
that is difficult

22
00:01:20.020 --> 00:01:24.900
if not impossible to copy and then be able
to execute on it effectively every day.

23
00:01:26.150 --> 00:01:29.180
And this goes for
an individual or a business.

24
00:01:29.180 --> 00:01:30.620
And let me say that again.

25
00:01:30.620 --> 00:01:34.990
You've got to bring something that's cool,
exciting, unique, compelling, that your

26
00:01:34.990 --> 00:01:39.780
customers highly value, that they're
willing to reach in their pocket and

27
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:44.800
give you $5 or $50,000 or $50 million for,
happily, because they see the value in it.

28
00:01:44.800 --> 00:01:49.602
That is unique,
difficult if not impossible to copy,

29
00:01:49.602 --> 00:01:53.200
and that you can actually
flawlessly execute on it and

30
00:01:53.200 --> 00:01:56.270
deliver it to your client exactly
the way you said you would.

31
00:01:56.270 --> 00:01:58.270
I wanna challenge you to sit down and
think about that.

32
00:01:59.810 --> 00:02:03.140
What does your business bring to
the marketplace that's exciting,

33
00:02:03.140 --> 00:02:05.090
compelling, unique, wow.

34
00:02:05.090 --> 00:02:09.630
That your customers very highly value,
that your competition can't copy, and

35
00:02:09.630 --> 00:02:12.290
that your company can deliver flawlessly

36
00:02:12.290 --> 00:02:14.990
every single time to every
one of your customers.

37
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:18.070
But let's take that a step further and
an even bigger challenge.

38
00:02:18.070 --> 00:02:23.030
What do you bring to the marketplace as
a sales person that meets that criteria?

39
00:02:23.030 --> 00:02:26.570
What do you do that's unique,
exciting, compelling, wow?

40
00:02:26.570 --> 00:02:30.580
That your customers find highly
valuable that it's difficult for

41
00:02:30.580 --> 00:02:35.550
other sales people to copy it and that
you can actually deliver it every time.

42
00:02:35.550 --> 00:02:40.120
If you can figure that out, you have
created an incredible differentiate in

43
00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:45.390
the market place, a huge market
advantage and you will truly position

44
00:02:45.390 --> 00:02:50.710
yourself as a high-level consultant,
a high-level trusted advisor,

45
00:02:50.710 --> 00:02:55.510
and among the best in your industry,
possibly at the world of what you do.

46
00:02:55.510 --> 00:02:57.460
Which is the next thing
I wanna share with you.

47
00:02:57.460 --> 00:02:59.020
How do you do that?

48
00:02:59.020 --> 00:03:03.840
Years ago, more than 20 years ago,
when I decided to get into this business

49
00:03:03.840 --> 00:03:07.530
I decided if I was gonna become
a professional speaker, a trainer,

50
00:03:07.530 --> 00:03:12.360
a consultant, that I wanted to
be the best I could possibly be.

51
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:15.670
I wanted to be among the top
in the world at what I did.

52
00:03:16.800 --> 00:03:20.400
So to do that, what I did is I looked
around at everybody in my industry, and

53
00:03:20.400 --> 00:03:24.450
I looked for the person that I
thought was doing the absolute best,

54
00:03:24.450 --> 00:03:26.990
the person who was
number one in the world.

55
00:03:26.990 --> 00:03:31.170
And at the time I came into this industry,
it was Tom Peters.

56
00:03:31.170 --> 00:03:34.310
This is the early 90s, he had just
written In Search of Excellence,

57
00:03:35.370 --> 00:03:38.460
he was doing circuits all over the world.

58
00:03:38.460 --> 00:03:41.296
He was working for the White House,
he was working for every major company.

59
00:03:41.296 --> 00:03:47.428
He had just been on Time Magazine as
the Uber guru of management consulting.

60
00:03:47.428 --> 00:03:52.040
So here's what I did, I said okay,
if that guy is number one in the world

61
00:03:52.040 --> 00:03:55.290
what do I have to do to
earn that same position?

62
00:03:55.290 --> 00:03:57.180
And I went to school on Tom Peters.

63
00:03:57.180 --> 00:03:59.427
I read everything I could about him.

64
00:03:59.427 --> 00:04:03.410
I read his books, I studied his
background, I went to his website.

65
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:05.780
I looked at all the articles
he had written.

66
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:09.270
I did everything I could to learn
everything I possibly could about

67
00:04:09.270 --> 00:04:13.540
how did Tom Peters become number
one in the world at what he did.

68
00:04:13.540 --> 00:04:15.080
And then I created a checklist.

69
00:04:16.815 --> 00:04:21.395
He's got massive research, he worked for
a top consulting firm, he's worked for

70
00:04:21.395 --> 00:04:23.355
top CEO's, top companies.

71
00:04:23.355 --> 00:04:28.465
He's done international work, he's got
best selling books, he's won major awards.

72
00:04:28.465 --> 00:04:33.615
I mean, I put it all down in a list and
then I said to myself every single day,

73
00:04:33.615 --> 00:04:36.530
what do I have to do to check
something else off that list?

74
00:04:36.530 --> 00:04:39.590
What do I have to do to get up today and
check something off that list and

75
00:04:39.590 --> 00:04:42.360
get one step closer to what it takes.

76
00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:43.650
Not fake it until you make it.

77
00:04:43.650 --> 00:04:46.880
To what it actually takes to be considered

78
00:04:46.880 --> 00:04:49.250
one of the best in
the world at what I did.

79
00:04:49.250 --> 00:04:52.290
Now there's a funny little story here
because about halfway through that

80
00:04:52.290 --> 00:04:56.030
journey, I actually met Tom Peters.

81
00:04:56.030 --> 00:04:58.840
I went to the World Business Forum,
where he was a speaker.

82
00:04:58.840 --> 00:05:03.540
And for an additional amount, you could
pay to have lunch with Tom Peters and

83
00:05:03.540 --> 00:05:07.730
about 100 other people and
a couple of very high level CEOs.

84
00:05:07.730 --> 00:05:12.150
And during the lunch, I got a chance
to sit and talk with him just briefly.

85
00:05:12.150 --> 00:05:15.175
And I told him, I'm coming after you.

86
00:05:15.175 --> 00:05:17.940
[LAUGH] I want to be where you are.

87
00:05:17.940 --> 00:05:22.570
I'm a speaker, I'm a consultant, I'm
early in my career, but my goal is to be

88
00:05:22.570 --> 00:05:27.640
considered among the best in the world,
equal with you or close to equal with you.

89
00:05:27.640 --> 00:05:31.085
He was polite, he smiled, and
basically said, good luck son.

90
00:05:31.085 --> 00:05:34.968
[LAUGH] Because I'm sure he's
heard that a zillion times before.

91
00:05:34.968 --> 00:05:39.280
But it didn't dissuade me at all.

92
00:05:39.280 --> 00:05:41.290
I just kept checking stuff off that list.

93
00:05:42.350 --> 00:05:48.650
And in 2015, I was named one of the top
100 business thought leaders in America.

94
00:05:48.650 --> 00:05:52.180
I was on a list of the top 100
business thought leaders in the world.

95
00:05:52.180 --> 00:05:56.300
I was named one of the top 50 leaders to
watch in America along with Sergey Brin

96
00:05:56.300 --> 00:06:00.263
and Larry Page from Google,
Jeff Bezos from Amazon.

97
00:06:00.263 --> 00:06:04.120
Was named one of the top 50 small
business influencers in America.

98
00:06:04.120 --> 00:06:06.850
One of the top,
well we won't even go into it.

99
00:06:06.850 --> 00:06:10.560
I won a bunch of a awards and
one of the most important was

100
00:06:12.290 --> 00:06:17.600
top 100 business speakers
Experts in America.

101
00:06:17.600 --> 00:06:22.040
And I looked at the list and it was in
alphabetical order and there just four,

102
00:06:22.040 --> 00:06:26.670
five names ahead of me was Tom Peters,
Peters Spence.

103
00:06:26.670 --> 00:06:30.160
I finally made it,
I was right on the list with him.

104
00:06:30.160 --> 00:06:34.430
And I sent him a note, this is on October,
I sent him a note and said, well,

105
00:06:34.430 --> 00:06:37.360
I did it I don't know if you remember, but

106
00:06:37.360 --> 00:06:40.540
about seven years ago,
I told you I was coming after you.

107
00:06:40.540 --> 00:06:43.510
I was gonna try to get even with you and
this year I made it.

108
00:06:43.510 --> 00:06:45.800
We're on a couple of lists together and

109
00:06:45.800 --> 00:06:48.780
I just wanna let you
know that I did make it.

110
00:06:48.780 --> 00:06:54.400
And for Christmas that year, I got a hand
signed, leather collector's edition,

111
00:06:54.400 --> 00:06:58.110
leather bound collector's edition
of In Search of Excellence,

112
00:06:58.110 --> 00:07:01.670
Signed by Tom Peters,
that said congratulations, you caught me.

113
00:07:01.670 --> 00:07:04.120
Now I don't tell you this to impress you,
but

114
00:07:04.120 --> 00:07:06.635
to impress upon you, I am not that smart.

115
00:07:06.635 --> 00:07:09.440
[LAUGH] I failed out of
college on the first try,

116
00:07:09.440 --> 00:07:11.620
did a little bit better on the second try.

117
00:07:11.620 --> 00:07:15.760
But if you truly wanna be among
the best in the world at what you do,

118
00:07:15.760 --> 00:07:17.530
it's pretty straight forward.

119
00:07:17.530 --> 00:07:18.220
Sit down and

120
00:07:18.220 --> 00:07:22.305
figure out, what did the best people
in my industry do to become the best?

121
00:07:22.305 --> 00:07:22.900
Who are the top salespeople?

122
00:07:22.900 --> 00:07:25.540
Who are the top consultants?

123
00:07:25.540 --> 00:07:28.940
Who are the best of the best
that everybody looks up to?

124
00:07:28.940 --> 00:07:33.090
And then find out everything you
can about what they actually did

125
00:07:33.090 --> 00:07:35.190
to earn that position.

126
00:07:35.190 --> 00:07:38.790
What did they learn, what degrees do
they have, what expertise do they have,

127
00:07:38.790 --> 00:07:41.140
what kind of connections,
what companies do they work with,

128
00:07:41.140 --> 00:07:44.780
what awards have they won,
what journals do they write in.

129
00:07:44.780 --> 00:07:47.200
You know, study them, go to their website.

130
00:07:47.200 --> 00:07:51.920
If you're lucky, pick up the phone and
call them or send them an email, and

131
00:07:51.920 --> 00:07:57.370
create a real specific, focused list
of all the things you've gotta,

132
00:07:57.370 --> 00:08:02.750
give, get, or give up to pay the price
to actually do everything on that list.

133
00:08:02.750 --> 00:08:06.720
And I can promise you from personal
experience, in just 17 years,

134
00:08:06.720 --> 00:08:08.620
you're an overnight success.

135
00:08:08.620 --> 00:08:13.390
So that's another idea about being
the best in the world at what you do and

136
00:08:13.390 --> 00:08:15.240
how to actually achieve that.

137
00:08:15.240 --> 00:08:17.950
I want to share two more ideas
with you about how to become

138
00:08:17.950 --> 00:08:19.010
truly great at what you do.

139
00:08:19.010 --> 00:08:24.120
As one of my friends in
Canada Dave Katz says epic [LAUGH].

140
00:08:24.120 --> 00:08:28.140
And the first one, again, is very simple.

141
00:08:28.140 --> 00:08:33.340
But extremely few people do this and
it's the idea of life long learning, or

142
00:08:33.340 --> 00:08:36.860
what I like to call personal
continuous incremental improvement.

143
00:08:38.070 --> 00:08:44.940
If you're not dedicating 10 or 15% of your
time to learning, improving your skills,

144
00:08:44.940 --> 00:08:49.270
getting new knowledge, reading books,
studying, watching videos,

145
00:08:49.270 --> 00:08:52.670
reading blogs There's no way in
the world you'll become world class.

146
00:08:52.670 --> 00:08:54.010
IT's just that simple.

147
00:08:55.130 --> 00:08:57.760
Let me give you an example
of how easy this is.

148
00:08:57.760 --> 00:09:02.330
How many book do you think the average
college graduate reads per year for

149
00:09:02.330 --> 00:09:04.270
self improvement or business improvement.

150
00:09:04.270 --> 00:09:06.330
To get better at their life or

151
00:09:06.330 --> 00:09:12.250
better as you know a sales person per
year after they graduate from college.

152
00:09:12.250 --> 00:09:14.160
The answer is 0.5, a half a book.

153
00:09:15.240 --> 00:09:19.210
I saw a couple of statistics lately that
said the average business person reads

154
00:09:19.210 --> 00:09:20.960
one business book every five years.

155
00:09:22.140 --> 00:09:26.540
I also saw another one that said if you
were to pick one topic in business and

156
00:09:26.540 --> 00:09:29.130
read it for one hour a day,
seven days a week for

157
00:09:29.130 --> 00:09:33.770
seven years, you'd be considered
a national authority on that topic.

158
00:09:33.770 --> 00:09:37.300
To give you an example of how I won
some of those awards, I've been reading

159
00:09:37.300 --> 00:09:42.380
a minimum of 100 to 120 business
books a year, every year since 1989,

160
00:09:42.380 --> 00:09:47.220
and that does not include
the numerous audiobooks I listen to,

161
00:09:47.220 --> 00:09:52.350
the white papers, the blogs, the Harvard
articles, everything I get my hands on.

162
00:09:52.350 --> 00:09:53.350
Constantly learning.

163
00:09:53.350 --> 00:09:55.110
And now, don't forget,
this is part of my job.

164
00:09:55.110 --> 00:09:59.240
I mean, I'm supposed to be knowledgable
and competent in what I do and

165
00:09:59.240 --> 00:10:02.940
an expert in business,
but the bar is very low.

166
00:10:02.940 --> 00:10:06.540
I mean if you were to
read six books a year,

167
00:10:06.540 --> 00:10:08.670
you'd be in the top 1% in
the United States of America.

168
00:10:08.670 --> 00:10:12.250
Six self help business books a year,
top 1% in America.

169
00:10:12.250 --> 00:10:16.440
If you read 12 books in a year,
you'd be in the top 1% in the world.

170
00:10:16.440 --> 00:10:21.340
So I'm going to stand right here and
tell you with tremendous confidence

171
00:10:21.340 --> 00:10:26.090
If you dedicate yourself to life-long
learning, to watching videos, listening to

172
00:10:26.090 --> 00:10:31.380
audiobooks, reading, studying, and
you give ourself 15% of your time.

173
00:10:31.380 --> 00:10:33.500
Just watch a little bit less TV.

174
00:10:33.500 --> 00:10:37.450
Get off Facebook for a little bit more.

175
00:10:37.450 --> 00:10:39.380
And invest it in yourself.

176
00:10:39.380 --> 00:10:43.240
I promise you you will look up three,
four, five years from now and

177
00:10:43.240 --> 00:10:45.420
you will crush the competition.

178
00:10:45.420 --> 00:10:47.800
Very, very, very few people do this.

179
00:10:47.800 --> 00:10:51.580
It's easy but it takes self-discipline and

180
00:10:51.580 --> 00:10:57.000
you've got to realize that every book you
read, every video you watch is helping

181
00:10:57.000 --> 00:11:00.760
you become better and will help you
make more money and be more successful.

182
00:11:00.760 --> 00:11:02.380
And when you think about it that way,

183
00:11:02.380 --> 00:11:04.950
you realize it's a great
investment of your time.

184
00:11:04.950 --> 00:11:07.930
Last idea I want to share with you comes
from a friend of mine, Tim Sanders,

185
00:11:07.930 --> 00:11:10.630
who wrote a great book called
Love Is The Killer App.

186
00:11:10.630 --> 00:11:14.950
Actually, Tim has written a bunch of great
books, and he's a phenomenal speaker, but

187
00:11:14.950 --> 00:11:17.780
in this particular book he talked
about the three things that it

188
00:11:17.780 --> 00:11:22.510
takes to build a world class career, and
I think he's just dead spot on here.

189
00:11:22.510 --> 00:11:27.830
And here are the three things K,
N, and L, KNL.

190
00:11:27.830 --> 00:11:33.420
The K stands for knowledge, you've gotta
be bright, sharp, smart, and talented.

191
00:11:33.420 --> 00:11:36.480
You've gotta have skills,
abilities, ideas, innovations,

192
00:11:36.480 --> 00:11:39.220
that are highly valuable
in the marketplace.

193
00:11:39.220 --> 00:11:41.140
You've gotta have information and

194
00:11:41.140 --> 00:11:46.880
creativity and ideas and knowledge
that people highly, highly value.

195
00:11:46.880 --> 00:11:50.890
If you've got a lot of knowledge
that people don't value,

196
00:11:50.890 --> 00:11:52.510
that doesn't help you
much with your business.

197
00:11:52.510 --> 00:11:56.150
So, its gotta be information ideas that
people in the marketplace highly value,

198
00:11:56.150 --> 00:11:57.780
key idea there.

199
00:11:57.780 --> 00:12:00.530
The next letter N stands for network.

200
00:12:02.250 --> 00:12:05.470
And by network, I mean what I call hubs.

201
00:12:05.470 --> 00:12:08.930
People that by the nature of who they are,
if they're really impressed with your

202
00:12:08.930 --> 00:12:13.190
knowledge and the value you bring to the
marketplace, they don't tell a few people,

203
00:12:13.190 --> 00:12:17.450
they tell a few dozen, or a few hundred,
or a few hundred thousand, or

204
00:12:17.450 --> 00:12:21.180
a million, literally,
through social media.

205
00:12:21.180 --> 00:12:26.450
The future of word of mouth and
referrals is definitely social media.

206
00:12:26.450 --> 00:12:30.750
I won't say the future of sales is
social media, it definitely helps, but

207
00:12:30.750 --> 00:12:35.330
if you want to get lots and lots of
referrals and build your reputation,

208
00:12:35.330 --> 00:12:39.620
networking with people, that if they're
really impressed with your knowledge,

209
00:12:39.620 --> 00:12:42.340
can tell lots and lots of other people.

210
00:12:42.340 --> 00:12:43.570
That's super valuable.

211
00:12:43.570 --> 00:12:45.520
Let me give you a real quick example here.

212
00:12:45.520 --> 00:12:49.250
When I wrote my last book,
called Awesomely Simple.

213
00:12:49.250 --> 00:12:51.300
It's a good book, it won a few awards, but

214
00:12:51.300 --> 00:12:55.030
it wasn't wiping out the bestsellers list,
just put it that way.

215
00:12:55.030 --> 00:13:01.380
Actually, it was number 1131 on
the amazon.com bestsellers list.

216
00:13:01.380 --> 00:13:02.570
Not exactly impressive there.

217
00:13:03.960 --> 00:13:06.832
Until one person tweeted it.

218
00:13:06.832 --> 00:13:11.730
Guy Kawasaki,
the former evangelist for Apple.

219
00:13:12.840 --> 00:13:14.680
I don't know how he got the book,
I didn't send it to him.

220
00:13:14.680 --> 00:13:17.790
But he read it and
he tweeted, really nice book,

221
00:13:17.790 --> 00:13:19.989
enjoyed it a great deal,
I highly recommend it.

222
00:13:21.100 --> 00:13:26.150
I went from number 1131 to number 11 on
the Best Sellers list in about a day and

223
00:13:26.150 --> 00:13:30.360
a half, and got backordered for
four months at Amazon.com.

224
00:13:30.360 --> 00:13:31.210
It was unbelievable.

225
00:13:31.210 --> 00:13:35.270
I mean, I sold thousands of
books because of that one tweet.

226
00:13:35.270 --> 00:13:39.940
Because Guy Kawasaki, at the time,
had 1.2 million Twitter followers.

227
00:13:39.940 --> 00:13:42.890
Now, I'm not saying a bunch of
the people you do business with have 1.2

228
00:13:42.890 --> 00:13:45.050
million Twitter followers.

229
00:13:45.050 --> 00:13:49.640
But if it's somebody in an association and
an industry you sell to.

230
00:13:49.640 --> 00:13:54.450
If you sell locally, if it's your Mayor or
your Head of the Chamber of Commerce or

231
00:13:54.450 --> 00:13:57.320
the Head of Kiwanis or
something like that.

232
00:13:57.320 --> 00:14:01.920
If it's a customer that by the nature of
who they are deals with lots of other

233
00:14:01.920 --> 00:14:06.070
customers like yours
that are non-competitive.

234
00:14:06.070 --> 00:14:10.490
If one person really is impressed by your
knowledge and how valuable it is, and

235
00:14:10.490 --> 00:14:12.650
they've got hundreds or
thousands of connections.

236
00:14:12.650 --> 00:14:15.490
And then you've got the third thing,
the L, which is love.

237
00:14:16.510 --> 00:14:20.670
If you're a kind, honest,
high integrity, high character person,

238
00:14:20.670 --> 00:14:25.100
a person of love, a lot of the right
people know that about you, hubs.

239
00:14:25.100 --> 00:14:26.910
And they also know that you're extremely,

240
00:14:26.910 --> 00:14:30.560
extremely knowledgeable about something
that's valued in the marketplace,

241
00:14:30.560 --> 00:14:34.160
you have the foundation of
an absolutely world class career.

242
00:14:34.160 --> 00:14:37.100
So the three questions you
have to ask yourself everyday.

243
00:14:37.100 --> 00:14:38.570
What did I learn today?

244
00:14:38.570 --> 00:14:39.830
Who did I meet today?

245
00:14:39.830 --> 00:14:41.830
And did I live my values?

246
00:14:41.830 --> 00:14:45.690
If everyday you're learning and growing
and increasing your valuable knowledge,

247
00:14:45.690 --> 00:14:47.900
you're constantly networking
with anybody you can.

248
00:14:47.900 --> 00:14:50.260
But, especially with
people who are hubs and

249
00:14:50.260 --> 00:14:53.050
can introduce you to tons of other people.

250
00:14:53.050 --> 00:14:55.970
And you guard your reputation
with everything you've got.

251
00:14:55.970 --> 00:14:59.130
You're good at what you do and you do it
because you care about your customers.

252
00:14:59.130 --> 00:15:03.050
You have high competence,
high concern and strong character.

253
00:15:03.050 --> 00:15:06.594
You have the makings of being truly
world class as a salesperson.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:04.190 --> 00:00:08.039
In this section, I wanna share with
you what I would consider the tools of

2
00:00:08.039 --> 00:00:12.180
the trade of being a trusted advisor and
it's three key things.

3
00:00:12.180 --> 00:00:16.800
Asking very, very good questions,
being an intense listener and

4
00:00:16.800 --> 00:00:19.860
taking fantastic very thorough notes.

5
00:00:19.860 --> 00:00:21.290
So let's start with the questioning.

6
00:00:21.290 --> 00:00:24.783
To be really good as
a consultative salesperson,

7
00:00:24.783 --> 00:00:27.201
you have to act like a consultant.

8
00:00:27.201 --> 00:00:31.625
And the ways consultants help their
customers is being extremely,

9
00:00:31.625 --> 00:00:33.550
insanely curious.

10
00:00:33.550 --> 00:00:38.210
So it's your job to learn everything
you can about your customer and client.

11
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:39.440
Everything they'll share with you.

12
00:00:39.440 --> 00:00:40.640
You don't wanna be too aggressive.

13
00:00:40.640 --> 00:00:43.060
You can't ask them a thousand questions.

14
00:00:43.060 --> 00:00:47.990
So you wanna make sure that zero in and
pick a handful of expert questions,

15
00:00:47.990 --> 00:00:51.530
that are very focused that will give
you just the right information, for

16
00:00:51.530 --> 00:00:53.870
you to be able to give them
just the right solution.

17
00:00:53.870 --> 00:00:55.960
There are some tools
actually techniques but

18
00:00:55.960 --> 00:00:59.890
I don't like that word,
about how to be an expert questioner.

19
00:00:59.890 --> 00:01:01.910
And I'm gonna share a few of
those with you right now.

20
00:01:01.910 --> 00:01:04.140
The first one is what I call Cushions.

21
00:01:04.140 --> 00:01:05.860
Cushions sound like in order for

22
00:01:05.860 --> 00:01:09.020
me to be able to help you
could you tell me about it?

23
00:01:09.020 --> 00:01:12.850
In order for me to be able to serve
you better, could you share with me?

24
00:01:12.850 --> 00:01:15.240
So that I can come up with
a great solution for you,

25
00:01:15.240 --> 00:01:19.690
could you take five minutes and tell me
as much detail, whatever it might be.

26
00:01:19.690 --> 00:01:23.820
These are all questions that say I'm about
to ask you a difficult, challenging, or

27
00:01:23.820 --> 00:01:26.730
important question, but
I'm doing it to help you.

28
00:01:26.730 --> 00:01:30.900
To serve you, to help you,
to understand you, to not waste your time.

29
00:01:30.900 --> 00:01:35.020
And that's exactly what customer's
clients wanna hear from a salesperson is

30
00:01:35.020 --> 00:01:36.540
I'm focused, I'm prepared,

31
00:01:36.540 --> 00:01:39.990
I'm gonna ask just the right questions,
I don't wanna waste your time.

32
00:01:39.990 --> 00:01:42.490
The next one is which called
a Conditioning Statement.

33
00:01:42.490 --> 00:01:45.790
And a Conditioning Statement is something
you put on a front of a question

34
00:01:45.790 --> 00:01:49.880
that says, I learn something new,
I have new information, and

35
00:01:49.880 --> 00:01:52.400
because of that I have to
ask you this question.

36
00:01:52.400 --> 00:01:55.900
It sounds like I was looking
on your website and noticed.

37
00:01:55.900 --> 00:02:00.210
I read in an industry article about
